page.title: 03PAKEFIELD VILLAGE & EROSION
page.content: {Pakefield},once an important {fishing} village in the Middle Ages, is now part of Lowestoft. It is much smaller than it was at the beginning of the 19th century. The main reason for this is that the cliff and the town have been {eroded} by the sea. Before the groynes were contructed, the sea washed away much of the land and the houses that were built on it. Since 1800 over 200 acres and over 120 houses have been eaten up by the sea. The Parish church of All Saints and St. Margaret which, in 1800 was over a half mile from the sea, is now only 10 metres from the edge of the cliff. Traditionally the inhabitants of Pakefield have depended upon the sea and the soil for their living. Today, the fishermen's cottages are mixed with new properties - these are often used as {holiday} homes.
